Subject: Re: [neat] A Review of Activation Functions in SharpNEAT

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=utf-8

Great report Colin!

+1 Pablo and Ken=E2=80=99s question about what happens=
 with true ReLus (where x<0=3D0). 

Also, as you note, we expect evolution =
to perform better with more evaluations, and many of these functions get mo=
re evaluation since in this report you held wall clock constant and these a=
ctivations are faster. 

But it is also interesting to know how these funct=
ions perform holding the number of evaluations constant (which is often how=
 we report things for a variety of reasons). Would you mind letting us know=
 how these figures look holding the number of evaluations constant?

Finall=
y, I think it is safe for me to speak for many of us in saying that we thin=
k this is important work and we=E2=80=99d love to see these same results on=
 more/harder problems. If you are interested in doing those tests and all y=
ou lack is access to a supercomputer, I can volunteer the computing resourc=
es from U. Wyoming to give you the ability to conduct a larger study. I als=
o completely understand if you do not have the time to take that task on. 
=

Thanks again. I was just discussing with Ken and Joel recently that I thou=
ght ReLus (and other deep learning tricks) might really help neuroevolution=
 and was saying that someone should test that. It=E2=80=99s awesome to star=
t seeing data on this question!

Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Loy and Edith Ha=
rris Associate Professor in Computer Science
Director, Evolving Artificial =
Intelligence Lab <http://evolvingai.org/>
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@u=
wyo.edu <mailto:jeffclune@...>
jeffclune.com <http://jeffclune.com/>

=

> =

>

ions get more evaluation since in this report you held wall clock constant =
and these activations are faster. 
> 
> But it is also interesting to know =
how these functions perform holding the number of evaluations constant (whi=
ch is often how we report things for a variety of reasons). Would you mind =
letting us know how these figures look holding the number of evaluations co=
nstant?
> 
> Finally, I think it is safe for me to speak for many of us in =
saying that we think this is important work and we=E2=80=99d love to see th=
ese same results on more/harder problems. If you are interested in doing th=
ose tests and all you lack is access to a supercomputer, I can volunteer th=
e computing resources from U. Wyoming to give you the ability to conduct a =
larger study. I also completely understand if you do not have the time to t=
ake that task on. 
> 
> Thanks again. I was just discussing with Ken and Jo=

> 
> Best regards,

ce

>> On Jun 20, 2017, at 1:03 AM, kst=
anley@... <mailto:kstanley@...> [neat] <neat@yahoogroup=
s.com <mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com>> wrote:
>> 
>> Great study Colin, thank=
s very much!  That was really interesting.  It suggests maybe sigmoid is no=
t the best option anymore, similarly to the trend in deep learning.  
>> 
>=
> I wonder, have you seen this new kind of activation function called SELUs=
 (scaled exponential linear units)?  It seems people are saying they are be=
tter now than ReLUs.  The paper below describes them, but I've heard they'v=
e been doing well on more than just what's in this paper:
>> 
>> https://ar=
xiv.org/abs/1706.02515 <https://arxiv.org/abs/1706.02515>
>> 
>> I wonder h=
ow they would impact neuroevolution.
>> 
>> Best,
>> 
>> ken
>> 
>> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_C1A1F753-0550-425F-B54F-4152E1E5BCBD

margin: 0px 0px 1em;" class=3D"">Great study Colin, thanks very much! =
 That was really interesting.  It suggests maybe sigmoid is not the be=
st option anymore, similarly to the trend in deep learning. <span clas=
s=3D"Apple-converted-space"> </span><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;"=
 class=3D""><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D"">I wonder, have yo=
u seen this new kind of activation function called SELUs (scaled exponentia=
l linear units)?  It seems people are saying they are better now than =
ReLUs.  The paper below describes them, but I've heard they've been do=
ing well on more than just what's in this paper:<br style=3D"line-height: 1=
.22em;" class=3D""><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""><a rel=3D"=
nofollow" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"https://arxiv.org/abs/1706.02515" style=
=3D"line-height: 1.22em; font-family: Verdana;" class=3D"">https://arxiv.or=
g/abs/1706.02515</a><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""><br style=
=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D"">I wonder how they would impact neuroev=
olution.<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""><br style=3D"line-hei=
ght: 1.22em;" class=3D"">Best,<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""=
